By the way large investment, low per-customer income means that, even if ISPs had gone there without government incentives - they would STILL have been a monopoly.
Because a large investment and low sales margine is the definition of a natural monopoly. It is NEVER worth it for a competitor to appear when those conditions hold - because the other company always has the advantage of having made part of their investment back already. Such cases the market can ONLY EVER be a monopoly.

So making it a government monopoly actually reduces the harm of the monopoly - because that means you can at least make some rules to limit how much it would be abused.
Chances are- in many places nothing would exist, and the others - there would be a monopoly just as there is now.

I applaud your decision to present the story on Mark Sargent. I think everyone deserves a voice. I do want to take issue (a little bit) with you on the line "Whether I like it or not the phenomena of fake news is real."

Fake news is neither new nor a phenomena of our times or the Internet. Disinformation and propaganda have been a tool of governments and other organizations for as long as the concept of reading and writing have been around. Hieroglyphics probably include some. 

We have a President who decries "fake news" while he himself spreads disinformation and propaganda freely and widely. However, he fits right in with most merchandising and popular organizations. Every person and group with a "belief" will promote that "belief" with their biases intact.

Meanwhile, any reporter and paper willing to fairly present people's opinions, beliefs, and actions without presenting judgement is a vital voice to maintaining a free population.

What Libby Unthank Tower advocates for is crucial, not least in light of what's happened to the rock 'n' roll bar scene in Eugene that produced the likes of the Searchin' Soul Blues Band in the late '60s and the Robert Cray Band and Curtis Salgado in the 1970s and how, according to Martin Scorsese, "Cinema is gone" (Register-Guard, 12/27, C4), for just two immediate examples. But it's also important to make explicit what Unthank Tower implies. For "culture" is not only music, books and our heritage. It is those patterns of meaning any group or society uses to interpret and evaluate itself and its situation. It is the symbolic and learned aspects of society transmitted not biologically but via social interaction. Nor can culture be reduced to, or explained away by, economic and political factor, though of course those factors certainly do influence -- without determining -- culture for good and ill, as Unthank Tower and the plight of rock 'n' roll and cinema demonstrate vividly.
